response.answer_text: I have grown up listening to my elder brothers’ mischieves. Now these guys are twins. So you can imagine: two hyperactive children, perched into a single home, since birth. Hell has a different name, people. When they were two, for instance. They found a basket. They got under the basket. And wouldn't you know they are up and about on our terrace . . . which didn't have railings. My mom had a simple rule. If the house is silent, Hell's gone loose. So my supermom, with her superhearing ability, hears people from 100 or more metres away on the terrace of a different building screaming for my brothers to stop. And up she goes, with her supermom superspeed. Time? Meh! The clock trembles to register another tick lest my supermom's gaze should crumple it to pieces. I still laugh my brains out when I hear her voice imitate their voices as she had picked them up: “Train is moving, brother.” *Giggles like a two year old* “Choochhoooo.” (Did I mention my supermom was born with her supersarcasm like every other Indian mom?) Oh but you know, this doesn't even clear the top ten of most silly and dangerous things they have earned for themselves! They deserve a limerick for that: Ooooh, they have cut each other. Broke each other,Torn each other's clothes. They have stitches on their heads,And scars on their brows! Their valiant methods, all uncrownedHave so been renooooowned. There was a little time,I remember clearly.They burnt the caterpillar,With pure gasolineYes you read it right.There's not a fight.They had burned the guyWith gasooooolllllliiiiiinnnneeee! (And mind you they were then fifteeeeeennnnn!) Still tip of the iceberg, guys. But let's not dwell on their ‘trivialities’. What prompts my answer is recent. Four years ago. . . My aunt had a baby. So, that'd be the first baby I've actually seen grow up. But then one fateful unfortunate day . . . I get to keep my eyes on him. How hard could it be, right? Meh, my mom did it everyday. Wrong. I turn my eyes for a second, and poof, the little devil's gone. What the —? Neel? Dude? Where did you go? Oh my God, Neel come out from under the sofa! Dang it, Neel, get off the floor! NO! DON'T EAT THAT! JFC! Don't play with the fucking matchsticks! No, not even the blades! Oh dear Bloody Mary, get away from the broken glasses! Dear lord, no! Don't go on the frickin’ terrace! What da faq are you doing, Neel?! Da Faq, Neel! Get away from the socket, you idiot. NEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEL!  So you can imagine. A meek little kid. Broken to his soul. Staggering his way to his home. Leaning on his gate, his eyes weary from the pain of the wars. A soldier of might, carrying the dead weight of the utter lunacy. Imbecility. Stupid-frickin'-dity. That day, my dear readers, I wondered. And my voice weakly asked, “Mom…” “Uh-uhh?” “How in the bloody name of God did you manage to keep us alive?”  So yeah, what I wonder most in life is if our mom isn't a secret agent fighting against evolution to keep suicidal morons alive. I still wonder.

It is o.k. to think about faith issues, meaning of life, and afterlife; that is a wise thing to do. Regardless of how successful we are with our personal objectives, we may not feel good without addressing the high-level objective; the purpose of our existence. It is wrong to say ‘let us enjoy the journey and forget about the destination’ If you find yourself in a train, you should not enjoy the beautiful scenes before first ask: why am I here? Where is the destination? We should first ask ‘what is the purpose of life?’ What is the value of life if we do not know the purpose of that life? It is the greatest good for an individual to discuss virtue every day...for the un-examined life is not worth living – Socrates God is testing us in our short life on earth; the wealthy father has the right to test his children before distributing the wealth. Testing missions are not supposed to be easy and comfortable. The test questions are not supposed to be known in advance. There are hundreds of verses and teachings about that test as mentioned in the following answer: https://www.quora.com/How-do-we-know-our-purpose-of-existence-in-this-world/answer/Sabri-Shahin We have been asked to believe in God and Heaven but we have not seen God or heaven. Our fate will be determined based on that belief and on our good deeds. Why did God make it a difficult test for us? Although God knows what’s in our hearts and what each of us might do, he tests us and wants us to witness our own test results in order to admit that we have been fairly rewarded according to our achievements as recorded in the test results Before the wealthy father distributes his wealth, he may want to record which son is obedient, the records are not for the father who knows, but as a testimony for people who might question the justice of their father Although the wise teacher knows the hard-working student and the lazy student, he prepares regular exams as testimonies so that the students would not say that the teacher had favored some students over the others. Exams also urge students to get prepared in order to succeed God has empowered each of us to be happy and blessed. God does not predetermine plans for us. God has delegated that task to us, it is up to us to be blessed or to be cursed. The message that God has revealed to all prophets is: ‘Blessings for obedience and curses for disobedience’ All prophets taught that we can earn salvation by obedience, repentance, and good deeds to help others. “In obedience and repentance is your salvation” Isaiah 30:15 Based on the above, the obedient believer should be blessed in this life and should be saved in the afterlife. That is the truth which should set you free. Yes, I often wonder what would have happened if I had made different choices in life. Or how my life would have turned out if I had been born rich, or for instance, what if I was born in Japan? Or what if I had been born African American, or Hispanic, or even male? Would I be the same person, and does the concept of a soul exist? And if it does, how much of who I am is due to the existence of this “soul”, and how much is a product of being born a caucasian woman in the United States, a member of the working classes? Those are the sorts of things I ponder while thinking about the course my life has taken.

I wonder about how precious and fragile life is. Human babies take 9 months to grow and be born; yet, they take years before they can safely care for themselves. Life can be quickly and effortlessly snuffed out, whether some mindless boy killing ants with a magnifying glass or, a wreckless teenager swerving off the road by looking down at a text message. I wonder at the marvel of the diversity of liife, the seemingly endless variety of species. I wonder at the power of massive thunderstorm as the storm cloud rises up to over 40,000 feet; we seem insignificant in comparison; yet mankind is the greatest marvel of them all.

June 9, 2017. I wonder about greatness— What is the greatest question? Who has done the greatest thing? How easy is it to become great? Who is the greatest person? Can a great person be immortal? Is there justice in greatness? What has more justice than greatness? What is the best attitude towards greatness? How to strategize about greatness? What is great intelligence? What is a great problem? Or a great word? Who is it that loves greatness? Who is it that realizes greatness? When greatness comes, what will follow? What is the tendency of greatness? Who is greatness's god? What is great to the great? What is small to the small? What seems small to greatness? How is greatness truly great? How to make the world truly great? And, what is the next best thing if I fail? … Uileinian Games

Gottfried Leibniz  John Locke Yes, I did wonder a lot about the meaning of life. But before that I wanted to know about this universe in which all life is. I settled for the explanation given by German mathematician and philosopher Gottfried Leibniz (1646-1716) that the Universe is, in a restricted sense, the best possible one that God could have created. Leibniz emphasized the role of a benevolent deity in creating this, the best of all possible worlds, where everything exists in a perfect, pre-established harmony with everything else. In such a universe, meaning of life, as implied by John Locke (1632-1704) makes sense. He believed that in a natural state all people were equal and independent, and everyone had a natural right to defend his “Life, Health, Liberty and Possessions”. Those who do not get these ideas naturally have to be educated to understand them.
